description.desc1: The virtual representation of a PixelPusher. This node needs the LedStrip node
description.desc2: The PixelPusher is a cheap and highly versatile LED-controller.

Unique ID.descript: Each pixel pusher anounces itself with its IP and Mac address. If the node receives such an anouncement, it will be listed here and can be selected

Notes.note1: The PixelPusher is a very raw product and its documentation is very sparse and evenly distributed inside its user forum. At the end of this short intro you will find some links to the most usefull tasks like flashing a new firmware (which is actually very easy once you find the proper thread) and other usefull facts.
Notes.note2: The PixelPusher is connected to the computer you are running SPARCK on via a LAN. It requiers a little setup file that is stored on a memory stick which is plugged in the device itself. the setup file specifies what kind of led strips you have phyiscally attached. There are many different protocols and PixelPusher can talk most of them:
Notes.note3:
<li>	MBI6030 
	<li>	LPD8806 
	<li>	SD600A 
	<li>	WS2801 
	<li>	P9813 
	<li>	LPD6803 
	<li>	TLC59711 
	<li>	APA102 
	<li>	WS2811
Notes.note4: It is possible to attach different types of Led-Strips simultanious to the device.
Notes.note5: The easiest way to connect is to plug it into the same Router and assign it (inside the setup file) a unique IP address. Once the device is powered up it will tell the PixelPusher node automatically if its existence and the node connects.
Notes.note6: You will find much more relevant infos about the setup file inside the Hardware Config Guide (link at the top of this page)
